meanings.definition: To remove a load or cargo from a vehicle or container.
meanings.sent1: I helped my dad unload the groceries from the car.
meanings.sent2: The workers quickly unload the boxes from the delivery truck.
meanings.sent3: After a long trip, it felt good to finally unload the heavy suitcases.
meanings.sent4: She felt like a weight had been lifted off her shoulders as she began to unload her worries.
meanings.sent5: The image of the cargo ship slowly unloading its containers stayed with him for days.

meanings.definition: To get rid of or dispose of something unwanted or burdensome.
meanings.sent1: I need to unload these old clothes to make space in my closet.
meanings.sent2: He decided to unload his old furniture at the garage sale.
meanings.sent3: She jokingly threatened to unload all her chores onto her little brother.
meanings.sent4: The decision to unload her toxic friendships brought her a sense of relief.
meanings.sent5: The idea of unloading all her worries into the ocean and watching them float away comforted her.

meanings.definition: To release or express pent-up emotions or thoughts.
meanings.sent1: She needed to unload her frustrations about the project to her friend.
meanings.sent2: He felt better after unloading his worries during the therapy session.
meanings.sent3: The comedy show was a great way to unload stress and have a good laugh.
meanings.sent4: After a long day, she found solace in unloading her thoughts in her journal.
meanings.sent5: The song lyrics seemed to perfectly unload the emotions she couldn't put into words.
